_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is to inform all interested persons, including employees that Lopez Foods, Inc. is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (called Process Safety Management or PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (called RM program), Title 40 CFR Part 68, have developed policies, to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and processing of hazardous chemicals.  In this way we promote overall plant, worker, and public safety.  These programs enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosion, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and avoid physical property damage.



Our safety program is applied to any activity involving hazardous chemicals including any use, storage, handling or the on-site movement of such chemicals, or combination of these activities.



Any group of vessels which are interconnected and separated vessels which are located such that a hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release shall be considered a single process.



Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.



The plant's process entails processing of raw meat products is such a way as to prepare pre-formed and uncooked meat products for the fast food industry.  Meat products require refrigeration and freezing to preserve the products against spoilage during manufacturing, transportation and in retail stores.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are found in the process safety management program.  The PSM p

rogram places necessary checks and balances for maintaining a safe operating refrigeration system.  Training procedures are in place to insure that all maintenance employees responsible for maintaining the system receive recertification training every three years and any new employee receives training before conducting operations on the ammonia system.



Controls and equipment go through an intense check list to insure safe operation of the equipment by qualified maintenance engineers on a daily basis.  The system is maintained 24 hours a day seven days a week by qualified maintenance engineers.



The emergency action plan utilized is OSHA's regulation 29 CFR 1910.38.  This plan is in place for the safe evacuation of employees.  Training is given to all affected employees annually and before their duty assignment begins.  Evacuation exercises are conducted as needed to promote training and additional understanding of the program.



The emergency response team is designated to the Oklahoma City Fire Department.  The Oklahoma City Fire Department participates in the overall program and coordinates with management in areas of planning for emergencies and emergency operations.



Under the emergency planning and community right to know act (EPCRA) and under section 303 of EPCRA, local emergency planning committees (LEPCs) must prepare an emergency response plan for facilities in their planning district having toxic substance listed under EPCRA section 302 in excess of the threshold planning quantity established under that section.



The Oklahoma City LEPC has been furnished a copy of this company's "Emergency Action Plan."  This plan includes toxic end points of the worst case scenario for this facility.  The management of Lopez Foods, Inc. will continue to coordinate response and evacuation procedures with the committee to insure the public sector is protected.



If a toxic release occurs, Lopez Foods, Inc. has in its EAP plan, all necessary procedures in place to

promote an effective response if the need arises.  The emergency response procedures include all necessary persons and agencies to contact to insure the utmost protection to the public, environment and employees.



The planned changes to improve safety are to improve awareness in training programs concerning the safe operation of equipment when operating in the vicinity of ammonia or vessels.
